reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s core evaluative setup: defining “mostly-great” and “eutopia” as fractions of a best-feasible (99.99th percentile) future, and then drawing substantive pessimistic conclusions from how much value is “left on the table.” If that relativity-to-ceiling framing were rejected in favor of an absolute flourishing threshold, much of the paper’s ‘narrow target’/‘lost value’ rhetoric would lose force, so centrality is fairly high. However, the critique mainly points out a dependence on the denominator and demands a defense of counting foregone potential as morally weighty; it doesn’t directly engage the authors’ own normalization/betterness-based setup (50–50 gamble with extinction) or show an inconsistency within their framework. So it weakens the argument only modestly. The main point about ratio sensitivity is correct, but it somewhat overstates the paper as treating a common-sense utopia as a “moral catastrophe” merely because the ceiling rose (the paper frames this as opportunity cost/value loss, not necessarily ‘catastrophe’), hence less-than-perfect correctness. The critique is clear, tightly focused, and contains little to no dead weight.
title: Defining success relative to expanding potential makes fixed outcomes arbitrarily catastrophic
